title: The Unexpected Author
subtitle: Detective novelist Helena Morrison discusses her latest book tour and surprising encounters with fans.

cards.text: The book signing at the department store started at half past six, but Helena Morrison had told her publicist, Sarah, that she liked to arrive early, get familiar with the place and have a chat with the staff. There was already a crowd of a quarter past. Now, after twenty seven mystery novels, Helena Morrison was a success! Her Detective Inspector Rivers series had made it to the small screen; the first three episodes had been shown, to great critical acclaim, and Helena had become about as familiar a face to the public as they got. She'd been interviewed on television and had featured prominently in magazines. After all, becoming an 'overnight success' at one's seventies was quite newsworthy.
cards.question: In the first paragraph, what is said about the recent publicity surrounding Helena?
choices: It was partly due to her age.
It caused her some embarrassment.
It upset her critics.
It was envied by other writers.
cards.highlight: becoming an 'overnight success' at one's seventies was quite newsworthy

cards.text: At 6:30 on the dot, Adrian, the event organizer, introduced her, and to polite applause Helena picked up her copy of the latest Inspector Rivers story and began to read. About five minutes later, though, she stopped. Anything less made her feel that if she couldn't wait to get away; anything more risked losing the audience's attention.
cards.question: When Helena read from her latest novel, she
choices: chose the length of the extract carefully.
was not sure what the audience were expecting.
read for longer than she had originally planned.
was pleased with the audience's reaction.
cards.highlight: About five minutes later, though, she stopped. Anything less made her feel that if she couldn't wait to get away; anything more risked losing the audience's attention

cards.text: After the reading, people formed an orderly queue, and Helena signed their books, pausing to chat briefly with everyone, asking if they wanted any specific sort of dedication and making sure the spelling of their names was right. Helena looked down at her wrinkled hand as she signed. Hands were the first to go, she thought. The rest of her was remarkably well preserved. She had regained tall and lean. She hadn't shrunk or got fat like so many elderly women. Steel-grey hair, pulled back tightly and fastened at the back, framed the deep blue eyes in her strong thin face; her nose was slightly hooked and her lips thin. Not a face that smiled often, people thought. And they were right, even though it had not always been so.
cards.question: What is said about Helena's physical appearance?
choices: Her hairstyle did not particularly suit her.
Ageing had not had a terrible effect on it.
She normally took little interest in it.
The condition of her hands surprised her.
cards.highlight: The rest of her was remarkably well preserved

cards.text: 'You used to live up north, didn't you?' The man appeared to be about sixty, painfully thin, with a long, pale face. He was wearing faded jeans and a short-sleeved shirt. He held the book out for her to sign. Helena nodded. 'A long time ago.' Then she looked at the back of the book. 'Who would you like me to sign this to?' 'What was the name of the place where you lived?' 'It was a long time ago.' 'Did you go by the same name then?' 'Look, I...' 'Excuse me, sir.' It was Adrian, politely asking the man to move along. He did as he was asked, and left. Adrian brought Helena a glass of wine and she carried on signing. When it was all over, Adrian and the staff drove her home to a long hot bath.
cards.question: What does the phrase 'it had not always been so' (line 15) refer to?
choices: a commonly held opinion about Helena
Helena's face
the fact that Helena seldom smiled
Helena's attitude towards other people
cards.highlight: Not a face that smiled often, people thought. And they were right, even though it had not always been so

cards.text: Helena laid a hand on Sarah's forearm. 'No, my dear,' she said. 'I'll be perfectly all right. I'm not over the hill yet.' Sarah blushed. She had probably been told that Helena was prickly. Someone always warned the publicist. 'So, I'm sorry. I didn't mean to suggest anything like that. It's my job.' 'A pretty young girl like you must have far better things to do than drive an old lady home.' Sarah smiled and looked at her watch. 'Well, perhaps if I phone my boyfriend we could get some last-minute theatre tickets. But only if you're sure.'
cards.question: When the man spoke to Helena,
choices: she was unwilling to answer his questions.
she found his physical appearance frightening.
Adrian appeared to recognise him.
he clearly did not believe her answers.
cards.highlight: she was unwilling to answer his questions

cards.text: As she walked to the tube, Helena thought again about the strange man in the bookshop. She didn't like to dwell on the past but he had pushed her into a reminiscent mood, as had the recent newspaper photograph of she and the memories of her life there had come crowding back. Helena shuddered as she walked down the steps to the underground.

choices: She had a tendency to say the wrong things.
She did not have much experience as a publicist.
She disliked having to attend book signings.
She was anxious not to offend Helena.
cards.highlight: She was anxious not to offend Helena
